LHCb releases first set of data to the public

  • The LHCb collaboration has released data from Run 1 of the LHC to the public for the first time, allowing research to be conducted by anyone in the world. This data sample amounts to 20% of the total data set collected by the LHCb experiment in 2011 and 2012 and contains 200 terabytes of information obtained from proton–proton collision events filtered and recorded with the detector. The data is filtered, classified according to approximately 300 processes and decays, and made available in the same format as that used by LHCb physicists. It is accompanied by extensive documentation and metadata, as well as a glossary explaining several hundred special terms used in the preprocessing. The data is suitable for different types of physics studies and can be directly downloaded by anyone. Further data releases from the LHCb collaboration are planned in the future.

ALICE estimates how transparent the Milky Way is to antimatter

  • The ALICE collaboration has published an article in Nature Physics that presents the first measurement of the rate at which antihelium–3 nuclei disappear when they interact with normal matter. This data has been used to estimate the transparency of the Milky Way to light antimatter nuclei, which is important for understanding their propagation in the Galaxy and for guiding space- and balloon-based searches for dark matter. The transparency was estimated to be 50% for antinuclei originating from dark matter, and 25–90% for cosmic-ray collisions, depending on energy. This suggests that antinuclei can travel long distances in the Milky Way without being absorbed.

Fusion energy breakthrough by US scientists boosts clean power hopes

  • US scientists at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory have achieved a breakthrough in fusion energy, producing a net energy gain in a reaction for the first time. This could provide a reliable and abundant source of zero-carbon energy, and could help to reduce global energy prices and emissions. The experiment involved bombarding a tiny pellet of hydrogen plasma with the world’s biggest laser, and produced about 2.5 megajoules of energy. Analysis of the results is still ongoing, and a major scientific breakthrough will be announced on Tuesday. If this is confirmed, it would be a historic moment as scientists have been attempting to achieve net energy gain since the 1950s. Investment into fusion power has grown significantly in recent years, and the potential breakthrough has been described as “game-changing” by industry leaders.

The secret, vibrant life of Paris’s famed Père Lachaise cemetery

  • Père Lachaise cemetery in Paris is world-famous for being the resting place of famous writers, musicians, artists and thinkers. Since the ban on pesticides in parks and cemeteries in Paris, and since lockdown in March/April 2020, biodiversity has greatly increased in the cemetery. Benoît Gallot, the cemetery’s curator, has been sharing photos of the wildlife that reside among the tombs and giving a glimpse into the secret, vibrant life at the Parisian landmark. He has also published a book, La Vie Secrète d’un Cimetière (The Secret Life of a Cemetery), to demonstrate the positive side of death, which is still a taboo subject in France. Gallot has been responsible for maintaining the plots, some of which are historical monuments, and for making sure that the 4,000 trees and 1,000 shrubs are kept safe. 100 plots become available in Père Lachaise each year, and the two-square-metre plots cost more than 15,000 euros. Père Lachaise is a multifaceted cemetery, with people from all over the world sending Gallot items such as books and poems.

Why do some dogs chase squirrels? Study finds genetic links to canine quirks

  • This study combined data from 46,000 answers to questions about canine behaviour and DNA sequences from over 4,000 dogs, including wild and domestic, to pinpoint genetic variants linked to certain behaviours. The complexity of dog breeding over hundreds of years has left its mark in the genomes of different breeds, making it difficult to trace the genetic origins of behaviours. The study identified 10 distinct canine lineages and mapped behavioural traits to them, finding that sheepdogs, for example, tended to show predatory behaviour and aggression towards other dogs, while toy dogs tended to be nervous. Analysis of the associated DNA variants revealed a molecular pathway involved in forming connections between nerve cells, with potential implications for research into the biological basis of human behaviours.

Massive Global Study Shows Belief in Witchcraft Is More Abundant Than You Might Think

  • This study conducted by Boris Gershman from American University found that belief in witchcraft is widespread around the world, with about 1 billion people across 95 countries believing in it. However, the prevalence of these beliefs varies greatly from place to place. The study also found that belief in witchcraft is associated with weak institutions, low levels of social trust, and low innovation. Furthermore, it is related to individual-level factors such as education and economic security. Gershman argues that understanding witchcraft beliefs is important for governments, researchers, or aid groups in order to work effectively with local populations.

Wormhole Publicity Stunts: Past, Present and Future | Not Even Wrong

  • It discusses the current and future of wormhole publicity stunts in quantum gravity research. It explains that future stunts will involve connecting two quantum computers in two places with a quantum network. It also mentions a past stunt that received little attention, as the authors claimed “wormhole-inspired” rather than “wormhole teleportation”. The text concludes by noting that such stunts are ideal, as they can receive funding from various sources and access to equipment from tech companies.

How Do They Know This?

  • In ‘Bad Data’ by Georgina Sturge, readers are presented with examples of statistics that are flawed, manipulated for political reasons, or close to guesswork. It is argued that even crucial variables such as Gross National Income and life expectancy are shrouded in uncertainty, and it is demonstrated how statistics can be misused or misinterpreted. Sturge encourages readers to ask “How do they know this?” when presented with an impressive statistic, as it is often the case that they don’t really know.

Largest-ever analysis finds genetic links to smoking and drinking

  • This article discusses a new study that has identified over 3,500 genetic variations that potentially affect smoking and drinking behavior. The study included people with African, American, East Asian and European ancestry, and showed that the majority of genetic associations for drinking and smoking have similar effects across the different ancestries. However, the sample size did not capture global diversity in genetic ancestry or geography, and the researchers suggest that collaborations with other investigators could expand the study in the future.

items.content_html:
What Causes Alzheimer’s? Scientists Are Rethinking the Answer.

  • The amyloid cascade hypothesis proposed that amyloid plaques were the cause of Alzheimer’s disease, and this idea led to a collective goal of targeting the plaques and getting rid of them as a remedy. However, despite the lack of useful results, alternative models were largely ignored in favor of the amyloid explanation. After more research, it is now becoming clear that the amyloid cascade hypothesis is not the only factor involved in Alzheimer’s disease and that targeting amyloid could still lead to effective therapeutic treatments. The current focus is now on exploring small molecules that can penetrate into the cell and inhibit the enzymes that generate amyloid-beta.

Oldest-ever DNA shows mastodons roamed Greenland 2 million years ago

  • This study reveals that the northern tip of Greenland was home to mastodons, reindeer, and lush forests 2 million years ago, which is surprising given the region’s current barren landscape. Through extraction and sequencing of ancient DNA from frozen soil samples from the Kap København Formation, the research team was able to identify the species present in the ancient ecosystem, which included poplar, spruce and yew trees, as well as reindeer and mastodons. The findings suggest that past ecosystems can be differently composed than expected, and that organisms are capable of adapting to changing climates.

New kilonova has astronomers rethinking what we know about gamma-ray bursts

  • A recent discovery of a gamma-ray burst (GRB) lasting nearly two minutes, called GRB 211211A, has challenged the long-standing assumption that longer GRBs are the distinctive signature of a supernova. Scientists have identified the source as a “kilonova,” triggered by the merger of two neutron stars, which was previously assumed to only produce short GRBs. This hybrid event of a kilonova with a long GRB is surprising, and suggests that gamma-ray bursts are much more difficult to classify than previously thought. GRB 221009A, the most powerful gamma-ray burst yet recorded, could be the “birth cry” of a new black hole. There are two types of gamma-ray bursts: short and long; short-term GRBs last less than two seconds and are thought to come from neutron-star mergers, while long GRBs can last several minutes to hours and are thought to come from supernovae. GRB 211211A was relatively close at 1 billion light-years away, and analysis revealed a kilonova signature. This could offer a new way of studying how heavy elements like gold and platinum form in our universe.

Curse Words Around the World Have Something in Common (We Swear)

  • A study published in the journal Psychonomic Bulletin & Review found that curse words in several unrelated languages tend to lack the consonant sounds L, R, W, and Y. The finding suggests that some underlying rules may link the world’s languages, regardless of how different they are. Additionally, the researchers found that when native speakers of different languages heard foreign-sounding words, they were less likely to guess that words with L, R, W, and Y sounds were curses, suggesting that the sounds themselves are associated with non-sweary words.

Asymmetry Detected in the Distribution of Galaxies | Quanta Magazine

  • Researchers have found evidence of an asymmetry in the arrangement of galaxies in the sky, an effect that could point to unknown fundamental laws that operated during the Big Bang. When counting tetrahedra made up of four galaxies, the researchers found that tetrahedra oriented one way outnumber their mirror images. This is known as parity violation, and could be related to the matter-antimatter asymmetry puzzle. To test this hypothesis, physicists are looking for further evidence of parity violation in other data sets, and are studying inflation models that could have produced the signal.

How smallpox inoculation united America

  • The Contagion of Liberty by Andrew M. Wehrman traces the path of the smallpox-inoculation movement in the American Revolution and its impact on politics. It tells the story of how African knowledge of variolation and its eventual acceptance helped to protect communities against infectious diseases and unite the colonies in their journey towards independence from British rule. It also highlights the importance of public health initiatives in ensuring the safety of communities, and the dangers of neglecting public health initiatives and allowing misinformation and competing interests to take precedence.

Hand of Irulegi: ancient bronze artefact could help trace origins of Basque language

  • The Hand of Irulegi, an ancient bronze artefact discovered near Pamplona, has recently been identified as the oldest written example of Proto-Basque and has the potential to help scholars trace the development of the mysterious Basque language. Until now, scholars believed that the Vascones, an iron age tribe from whom modern Basque is thought to descend, were largely illiterate and only began writing after the Romans introduced the Latin alphabet. However, the five words written in 40 characters that were identified as Vasconic suggest otherwise, with the first word being a forerunner of the modern Basque word for ‘good luck’. Experts studying the artefact believe that it could change the way scholars look at the Vascones, as it indicates that they had a written language. Although the discovery is significant, caution should be used when extrapolating too many conclusions from it.

Paper-mill detector put to the test in push to stamp out fake science

  • Publishers are testing prototypes of automatic systems to detect submitted manuscripts that may contain fabricated data and images. The tools are part of an online integrity hub which is being developed by the International Association of Scientific, Technical and Medical Publishers in collaboration with 24 publishing companies. The hub will provide tools to editors to check submitted articles for research-integrity issues and will include two tools: one to scan papers for signals which could indicate a paper mill, and another to alert editors when a paper is submitted to multiple journals. The hub will also include an image-detection software and provide workshops for publishers to share information and learn from each other. It is funded by an initial, undisclosed, investment by STM, and operational costs will be recovered via a fee for integrating the hub into the publishers’ editorial systems.

How to think about truth

  • This document discusses philosophical ideas about truth and how it relates to understanding and navigating the world. It covers five ideas about truth, including that true beliefs pick out facts that exist independently of our beliefs about them, that our beliefs are biased, and that truth relativism is a view about what makes beliefs true or false. It also suggests that our cultures and languages can affect the beliefs we have about truth and that truth may be simpler than we think. The document offers a number of resources to explore these ideas in more depth.

(Not) A Wormhole in a Laboratory

  • Physicists have not created a real wormhole in a lab, nor have they studied quantum gravity in a lab. They have, however, made a baby step toward simulating a “toy model” of a wormhole in a lab. This method is analogous to trying to learn about the origin of life or consciousness through simulations. It is not the real thing and may lead to a simulation of a real wormhole in the distant future, but will never lead to making a real wormhole. The press has overblown the results of this experiment and it is unknown why physicists make claims beyond what they have actually done.

Peru mural that evaded looters’ clutches rediscovered

  • This article describes the rediscovery of a pre-Hispanic mural in Lambayeque, Peru that was believed to have been destroyed by looters a century ago. In 1916, looters attempted to demolish the temple containing the mural, but were stopped in the nick of time by authorities. The only remaining evidence of the mural was photographs taken by Heinrich Brüning, an ethnographer. In 2018, Swiss archaeologist Sam Ghavami and his Peruvian colleague Christian Cancho were able to excavate the temple and uncover a 100-foot wall painted in brilliant colors. The mural depicts a procession of warriors marching towards a deity with birdlike features, and is said to be an important transitional phase in northern Peruvian art.

As some hail new antibody treatment for Alzheimer’s, safety and benefit questions persist

  • The Japanese company Eisai and its partner Biogen have developed the monoclonal antibody lecanemab to remove a protein called amyloid-beta in early-stage Alzheimer’s. Clinical trial results showed that lecanemab, given by intravenous infusion every other week, slowed the rate of cognitive decline by 27% in people taking it for 18 months, compared with similar participants on a placebo. While many scientists and advocates are hailing these results as a success, some neurologists are still questioning its safety and benefits, as there is a risk of brain swelling and brain hemorrhages, and the benefit of 0.45 points on the dementia scale is not clear. Further research is needed to determine the safety and efficacy of lecanemab before it can be recommended to patients with Alzheimer’s.

New device can make hydrogen when dunked in salt water

  • This new device uses a membrane with carefully structured pores to separate seawater from a concentrated solution of potassium hydroxide (KOH). It works by allowing water molecules to pass through the membrane in the form of vapor, while leaving the salt molecules behind. The device is able to produce hydrogen when submerged in seawater without using extra energy, making it more efficient than a standard electrolyzer. It has been tested in Shenzhen Bay seawater and was found to be successful after 3,200 hours of use. The device could also be used for other purposes such as purifying contaminated water.

Method for solving notorious calculus problems speeds particle physics computations

  • This article discusses a new method of solving Feynman integrals, which are notoriously difficult calculus problems that are central to particle physics calculations. The method, developed by Liu and Ma, reduces the integrals to linear algebra problems and has been used in 80% of recent papers posted to the arXiv preprint server. It promises faster and more precise theoretical calculations, but still requires a significant amount of algebra and computer time.

First-time ATLAS measurement provides new look at Higgs

  • It discusses a first-time ATLAS measurement at CERN that provides a new look at particles called W and Z bosons, which are associated with the four fundamental forces in the universe. These bosons have a property called polarization, and by studying this, physicists are able to probe the mechanism that grants particles mass. How secure a Twitter replacement is Mastodon? Let us count the ways

  • Mastodon is a new social media platform that has seen a huge surge in monthly active users and total users in the past month. It is built on a federated model of independent servers and is more akin to email or IRC in terms of security. There are concerns about the security of the platform, as it has not undergone an official security audit and there is a wide range of skill levels of the volunteers running the servers. There have been several vulnerabilities discovered, including ones that allow for the downloading and deleting of all files on a server and stealing of user passwords. There is a risk of a high-security vulnerability in the software ecosystem Mastodon relies on, though it has not yet been exploited. There is also a risk of DDoS attacks, hacking of accounts, and harassment and misinformation campaigns.

Ruminations in an Emergency

  • Anatole France compared Marcel Proust to Bernardin and Petronius, suggesting that Proust reversed Bernardin’s preoccupation with the corruption of innocence and converted Petronius’ sensualism into an aesthetic vocation. Proust’s work, In Search of Lost Time, was an ambitious four-thousand-page reconstruction of a life and a world, touching on the Dreyfus affair, anti-Semitism, and French nationalism. Finding Time Again, the final volume, was written in a new style due to the author’s failing health and the effects of World War I. The Modern Library editors used the work of Andreas Mayor, which was often colored by heavy editorial hand. In the book, Proust’s errors are often allowed to stand, and there is a sense of haste, due to the author’s pain and guilt over Alfred Agostinelli’s death and his own inversion. The narrator is often cruel in his assessment of the characters and their decadence, and Proust, in the end, was like Scheherazade, weaving by night and unweaving by day in a feverish nocturnal composition. His goal was to create a book like an optician’s magnifying glass, offering readers the means to read themselves and to chronicle individual peculiarities.

Charles V of Spain Secret Code Cracked

  • Researchers from the Loria research lab in eastern France have cracked a 500-year-old code found in a letter written in 1547 by Emperor Charles V to his ambassador in France. The letter revealed fears of a French assassination plot against him and highlighted the tense relations between Charles V and France’s Renaissance ruler, Francis I. The code was deciphered with the help of computers and another letter with doodled transcription code in the margin. The discovery confirms the degraded state of relations between the two in 1547, and the researchers now hope to identify other letters between the emperor and his ambassador.

How the Great Depression shaped people’s DNA

  • This study found that people who were conceived during the Great Depression of 1929–1939 showed signs of accelerated aging in their cells. Their epigenome, which is the collection of chemical markers attached to DNA, was changed which led to higher rates of chronic illness and death. The findings show how social programs designed to help pregnant people can help fight health disparities in children. The study also showed that exposure to hardship can shape human health for decades and that experiencing a recession before birth can affect how long someone lives.

Physicists find quantum coherence and quantum entanglement are two sides of the same coin

  • The text explains the findings of a study that showed that quantum coherence and quantum entanglement are “operationally equivalent.” This means that they are equivalent for all practical purposes, though still conceptually distinct. The study also showed that coherence and entanglement can be converted into each other. This discovery has several important implications, one of which is that all of the knowledge that researchers have obtained about entanglement can now be directly applied to coherence. The operational equivalence of coherence and entanglement will likely have a far-reaching impact on areas ranging from quantum information theory to more nascent fields such as quantum biology and nanoscale thermodynamics.

The document also discusses how the Reddit page Illness Fakers (IF) attempts to identify these individuals and discusses the reaction of the online disability community to the issue.

items.content_html:
It Looks Like a Shell, but an Octopus and 40,000 Eggs Live Inside

  • The argonaut octopus has evolved the ability to produce a floating shell-like structure to care for its offspring. This shell-like structure is made of a mineral formula that is seceted by the octopus using two of its arms. The shell-like structure can grow to nearly a foot in length and can hold more than 40,000 embryos. The argonaut octopus crawls inside its shell-like purse, traps some air bubbles inside, then uses its buoyancy to bob just beneath the surface of water in warm oceans around the world. The argonaut octopus has evolved this ability independently, and not by reactivating archaic genes from the mollusk era. The argonaut octopus’s shell-like egg case didn’t evolve from the ancestral shell, but it is the argonauts’ own evolutionary innovation for a new purpose. The findings also feed into a debate over whether the argonaut’s egg case should really be called a shell. Michael Vecchione of the National Museum of Natural History wishes people wouldn’t call it a shell because there’s a major difference in how it’s constructed. Other mollusks make their shells with mantle tissue secreted by a gland, Dr. Vecchione said, whereas the arm tips of A. argo secrete the argonaut’s shell material. He hopes these novel findings will finally convince people to stop calling it a shell and start a rebrand. Beyond the shell debate, Dr. Setiamarga and colleagues’ new genome sequence may help scientists understand more about how argonauts evolved to be pelagic, or living in open waters, and not benthic, like other octopuses who prefer the depths.

Murakami On Writing

  • A book review of “Novelist as a Vocation” by Haruki Murakami. The reviewer summarizing the book states that it is a collection of essays that offer insight into Murakami’s profession, and that the author is at pains to stress that these are simply his own thoughts and experiences and that he is not really giving advice at all. The reviewer goes on to say that, despite his success, Murakami remains painfully self-effacing, telling us that he is “ordinary” and unintelligent, and he often seems to be baffled (and even troubled) by what he has achieved. The reviewer also states that the book is notably bereft of personal detail and it is filled, instead, with already well-established moments from his life—a handful of stories he has rehashed endlessly in interviews and essays, perhaps hoping to deflect any meaningful inquiry into his life.

Strange black hole merger may have been a rare random encounter

  • In short, researchers are suggesting that the GW190521 black hole merger may have been the product of two black holes finding each other in the vastness of space, rather than the product of two massive stars that formed as a binary system. This is based on the fact that the GW190521 signal did not fit templates especially well and only matched best if the black holes involved weren’t spinning at all. The chirp was unusually short, and there is no sign of a signal prior to the actual merger. Finally, both of the objects involved in the merger were relatively massive: about 50 and 80 times the mass of the Sun. Black holes of this size don’t form in supernovae (those typically start out with less than 15 solar masses), so these are likely the products of prior collisions.
